Summary: Artificial intelligence-driven automation has gradually become the technical trend of the new automation era. In this article, we model the learning and decision-making process of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with a statistical physical percolation model. Based on the differentiation degree and vulnerability, the relationship between the classification reliability and the physical model is constructed. A theoretical explanation is provided for the difference in reliability among CNNs with different structures and learning abilities. The relationship between the differentiation degree and vulnerability is analyzed from both adversarial attack and adversarial training perspectives. Experimental results in the industrial automation domain verify the validity and universality of the model.

Summary: The paper proposes a two-stage method (OEC-IRRL) for achieving submillimeter-precision robotic insertion tasks using only visual inputs, targeting challenges in flexible, semi-structured industrial settings where component position and orientation vary. Summary: This paper introduces Knowledge Graph-enhanced Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (KGMARL) as a novel framework for adaptive scheduling in self-organizing manufacturing networks under the mass personalization paradigm. The datasets and code are openly available at https://github.com/uoa-iai/scheduling_instances.

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges of flexible job shop scheduling problems (FJSP) in dynamic, personalized manufacturing environments, particularly within the IoMT (Internet of Manufacturing Things) context. The authors propose a graph-based multi-agent system (GMAS) leveraging a centralized-learning decentralized-execution (CLDE) approach underpinned by Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN), allowing efficient extraction of global coordination features from unstructured data arising in multi-agent interactions. FJSP is modeled using a probabilistic Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG), enabling flexible, consecutive scheduling aligned with the versatile functions of CNC machines and the requirements for small-batch or personalized production. The GMAS architecture includes environment, job agent, and machine agent modules, wherein job agents interact with machine agents and the environment in a decentralized manner, while GCN-extracted features inform centralized learning for global optimization. The scheduling strategy is formalized as a probability distribution over edge connections in the DAG, with optimization guided by a combination of expected makespan and machine load rates. Simulations on benchmark datasets (Brandimarte and Hurink) across various dynamic scenarios demonstrate that GMAS outperforms state-of-the-art rivals, offering superior makespan, robustness, adaptability, and scalability; it achieves the lowest CPU utilization (ACU) and data occupation (ADO) as complexity increases. Improved queuing rules further enhance machine utilization. The work thus presents a scalable, robust, and generalizable solution for dynamic and distributed FJSP, suitable for Industry 4.0 and smart manufacturing, though future challenges remain in multi-agent non-stationarity, learning diversity, and decentralized data security.

Summary: Spindle axial error is a primary limitation in achieving high machining accuracy in CNC machine tools, often exacerbated by challenges in acquiring real-time sensing data during machining due to space limitations and environmental interference. This study presents a novel approach utilizing a residual and skip connection enabled adaptive cosine annealing learning rate physics-informed neural network (RSAC-PINN) to reconstruct the spindle's temperature field during the warm-up phase, achieving an 82.10% increase in computation speed and 40.68% improvement in stability over standard PINN models. A long short-term memory (LSTM) model, optimized via grid search, predicts the temperature of the node most correlated with axial error, and machining is initiated when this node reaches a preset threshold determined by accuracy requirements. The relationship between spindle temperature and axial error is captured post turning point by linear regression, enabling real-time error prediction and compensation during machiningeven with sensors removedthus overcoming traditional sensing constraints. Experimental procedures on a factory CNC machine validated the method, with the error compensation group achieving cumulative deviations within 3 m, a remarkable 96.8% improvement over conventional practices. The methods adaptability allows warm-up time to be tuned for economic and quality considerations, and future work will extend its applicability to other machine types and incorporate additional error factors such as tool wear. The approach thus substantially enhances machining precision and process robustness in practical CNC operations.

Summary: The study addresses the challenge of optimizing job sequencing in manufacturing, focusing on a custom machine setup that balances precedence and additional constraints to minimize makespan. Citation: Edwin Omol, Paul Abuonji, and Lucy Mburu, "SMEs’ digital maturity: analyzing influencing factors and the mediating role of environmental factors," Journal of Innovative Digital Transformation, vol. 2, no. 1, pp. 19-36, 2025. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1108/JIDT-01-2024-0002

Summary: This paper develops a conceptual framework for digital transformation by integrating resource-based view (RBV) and service-dominant logic (SDL) to clarify how firms leverage both valuable, rare, inimitable, and nonsubstitutable (VRIN) and nonVRIN resources, including IT-based assets, to build higher-order (dynamic) and lower-order (ordinary) organizational capabilities that ultimately enhance firm performance. Citation: T.-Y. Wu and C.-Y. Lin, "Surface profile estimation in milling through vibration analysis and long short-term memory networks," International Journal of Advanced Manufacturing Technology, vol. 137, pp. 2047–2060, 2025. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1007/s00170-025-15291-7
Summary: This study presents a methodology for predicting the detailed surface profiles of milled workpieces using tooling vibration signals and cutting parameters, advancing beyond traditional surface roughness estimations. Vibration signals were reduced in dimensionality with principal component analysis (PCA) and decomposed into intrinsic mode functions (IMFs) via empirical mode decomposition (EMD), from which both statistical (\textit{e.g.}, RMS, peak-to-peak, mean, STD) and sweeping-frequency features were extracted in time and frequency domains. These features, alongside cutting parameters, were input into separate long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to estimate the corresponding IMFs of the surface profiles. Correlation analyses revealed that selected features, particularly those related to even multiples of the spindle speed (due to the tools two-flute geometry), significantly improved prediction performance. Experimental results with 168 datasets showed accurate prediction of mid- to low-frequency surface profile components, with mean absolute percentage errors (MAPE) of 14.72% for IMF-5 to IMF-12 and 7.79% for IMF-8 to IMF-12, while total surface profiles reached an overall MAPE of 24.17%. High-frequency IMFs were more difficult to estimate accurately due to noise and lower feature correlation. This approach enables more comprehensive, online assessment of surface quality in milling, and suggests potential for further enhancement by introducing additional advanced features. The research dataset is made available to support ongoing development and validation.

Summary: Global market competition and fluctuating customer demands require manufacturing enterprises to focus on cost reduction and efficiency improvement to increase competitiveness and sustainability. This research presents a new combined efficiency improvement methodology that integrates Lean methods with facility layout design (FLD), leveraging the advantages of both approaches for superior results compared to their isolated application. The main contribution is a novel combined method resulting in notable improvements in efficiency, cost reduction, and several key performance indicators (KPIs), substantiated by a real manufacturing plant case study. The study demonstrated that applying 13 Lean methods alongside FLD (which seeks to minimize material workflow, travel distance, material handling cost, and assembly space) improved 10 quantitative and 5 qualitative indicators: productivity, cycle time, number of workstations and operators, WIP (work-in-process) inventories, space used for assembly, material workflow, travel distance of materials, material handling cost, labor cost, component supply, products quality, transparency, standardization, and workplace ergonomics.

Citation: A. Dolgui, G. Levin, and B. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1080/00207543.2019.1627311
Summary: This paper addresses the optimal design of machining processes involving ordered operations, many of which may be mandatory, optional, nested, and potentially intersecting due to modern multi-tool capabilities. The authors highlight that intersecting sets of operationsarising from overlapping tool paths or concurrent setupsrequire careful aggregation into executable blocks, each with adjustable execution rates, in order to minimize total production time and cost under real-world process constraints (such as rigidity, collision avoidance, energy, and tool wear). The approach systematically models the process as a partially ordered set, encodes technological dependencies and intersections, and formulates a constrained optimization problem. For processes where intersections form a tree structure, a polynomial-time dynamic programming algorithm is described, while more general intersection graphs necessitate heuristics due to NP-hardness. Experiments, including an industrial case, reveal the method can reduce total machining time by 30% relative to naive approaches, with near-optimality (within 27% of the lower bound) for larger, complex instances. The discussion notes both practical advantages and limitationsespecially for highly complex intersection topologiesand outlines future directions such as advanced heuristics, predictive wear integration, and CAM system compatibility. Overall, this work provides a scalable framework for aggregate block formation and rate selection in multi-operation machining, validated by computational experiments and real-world case studies.

Citation: Y. Xiong, H. K. S. Lam, and S. Summary: Firms have been increasingly adopting virtual reality (VR) technologies for manufacturing purposes, but it is still unclear whether and how such VR-enabled manufacturing practices (VRMPs) can help firms improve production efficiency. Analyzing a sample of 87 US treatment firms that have adopted VRMPs and 87 matched control firms without such adoption over the period of 20102020, our difference-in-differences estimation suggests that the treatment firms gain more production efficiency improvement when compared with the matched control firms. We also find that the production efficiency improvement arising from VRMPs is more pronounced for firms facing high levels of labor volatility and market dynamism. Our additional analysis further suggests that applying VR technologies into different manufacturing stages and in different industrial sectors can result in different degrees of production efficiency improvement. Overall, our study demonstrates the positive effect of VRMPs on production efficiency but also reveals how the effect can vary across firms depending on their operating environments, VR application fields, and industrial sectors.

Citation: A. Belhadi, S. S. Kamble, M. Venkatesh, C. J. C. Jabbour, and I. Summary: This paper examines how Additive Manufacturing (AM) enhances both supply chain resilience and efficiencytermed ambidexterityby deploying a dynamic capability perspective. Using 28 interviews across six sectors (aerospace, automotive, electronics, energy, healthcare, machinery) in four countries, the authors find that AM enables exploratory learning (boosting resilience through rapid redesign, digital inventory, and flexible networks) and exploitative learning (driving efficiency via localized, on-demand production and resource savings). Four propositions emerge: (1) AM enhances resilience via exploratory learning; (2) AM improves efficiency via exploitative learning; (3) balancing both learning modes with AM leads to greater supply chain ambidexterity; and (4) digital integration with platforms (IoT, cloud) amplifies these effects. Barriers include high investment, lack of standards, IP concerns, integration challenges, and skills gaps. The study concludes that AM's true value arises when it is purposefully integrated into digital supply chain strategies, overcoming the traditional resilience-efficiency trade-off and positioning AM as a core capability for navigating ongoing disruptions.

Summary: Although digital investment is expected to achieve both economic growth and environmental conservation, little is known about the mechanisms through which it enhances environmental performance. This study, grounded in the natural resource-based view, investigates how digital investment influences environmental performance via the mediating effects of production efficiency and green innovation. Analyzing data from 273 Chinese pollution-intensive firms (totaling 1009 firm-year observations between 2016 and 2020), the research demonstrates that digital investment significantly improves environmental performance, with both production efficiency and green innovation serving as partial mediators. Notably, heterogeneity analysis reveals this positive impact is significant only in state-owned and heavy industrial firmsnot in private or light industrial firms. Moreover, the environmental benefits in heavy industrial firms stem from improved efficiency, while in state-owned firms, both efficiency and innovation mediate the effect. These findings provide actionable insights for managers and policymakers seeking to leverage digital investments for sustainable industrial development in the Industry 4.0 era.

Citation: V. Zelenyuk, "Productivity analysis: roots, foundations, trends and perspectives," Journal of Productivity Analysis, vol. 60, no. 3, pp. 229–247, Dec. 2023. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1007/s11123-023-00692-1
Summary: This article provides a comprehensive overview of productivity analysis, tracing its general concepts, historical evolution, and its central importance in economics and broader fields. After establishing the importance of productivitydescribed by Paul Krugman as almost everything in long-run economic developmentthe paper surveys a wide spectrum of productivity measurement methods, from simple indexes to sophisticated tools like the Malmquist Productivity Index (MPI), including their decomposition into efficiency and technological change components. Key analytical approaches covered include growth accounting, various index number theories (Laspeyres, Paasche, Fisher, Tornqvist), and efficiency measurement techniques such as Data Envelopment Analysis and Stochastic Frontier Analysis. The discussion highlights both theoretical developments and empirical illustrations, emphasizing advances made by Rolf Fare and Shawna Grosskopf, as well as statistical properties and inference methods relevant to MPI. Table-based bibliometric analysis is used to visualize the fields evolution. The article also critically examines the inherent challenges of productivity measurementsuch as aggregation methods, restrictive assumptions like Hicks-neutrality and constant returns to scale, and empirical inference issueswhile acknowledging the influence of data choices on conclusions about productivity trends. Future directions point toward unifying disparate methodologies, merging with causal inference and artificial intelligence, and integrating big data and real-time tools to support robust productivity analysis. Ultimately, the article underscores both the progress and persistent challenges in productivity analysis, emphasizing the need for continued methodological innovation and the collaborative, open-minded approach exemplified by leading scholars in the field.

Citation: L. Simar, V. Zelenyuk, and S. Zhao, "Further improvements of finite sample approximation of central limit theorems for envelopment estimators," Journal of Productivity Analysis, vol. 59, no. 2, pp. 189–194, Apr. 2023. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1007/s11123-023-00661-8
Summary: This paper proposes a new method to improve the finite sample approximation of central limit theorems (CLTs) for aggregates of data envelopment analysis (DEA) efficiency estimators, which are widely used for measuring efficiency in settings such as banks or hospitals. Recognizing that previous CLT-based confidence intervals tended to undercover true values in small sample or high-dimensional cases, the authors suggest estimating the variance using bias-corrected individual efficiency estimates ($\hat{\lambda}_i - \hat{B}_i$) instead of uncorrected estimates. The key equations are: the sample variance estimate used in Kneip et al. (2015) ($\hat{\sigma}^2 = n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^n (\hat{\lambda}_i - n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^n \hat{\lambda}_i)^2$), the partial variance correction by Simar \& Zelenyuk (2020) ($\tilde{\sigma}^2 = \hat{\sigma}^2 + \hat{B}^2$), and the new full variance correction ($\hat{\hat{\sigma}}^2 = n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^n [ (\hat{\lambda}_i - \hat{B}_i) - n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^n (\hat{\lambda}_i - \hat{B}_i)]^2$). Extensive Monte Carlo simulations show that, especially for small samples ($n\leq100$) and higher dimensions, this new method, particularly when combined with the 'data sharpening' approach, yields empirical coverage very close to nominal confidence levels (e.g., for $n=100, p=3, q=1$, coverage improves from 0.694 to 0.954). For the free disposal hull (FDH) estimator, the improvements are even more pronounced. The method requires no additional computational cost and keeps the asymptotic properties intact. Some overshooting (empirical coverage > nominal) may occur, but is safer than under-coverage, and for large sample sizes all methods become asymptotically equivalent. The authors note that further research could address residual first-order error terms and extend methods to other efficiency measures.

Citation: S. Emili and F. Galli, "Spatial and cross-sectoral input spillover effects: the case of the Italian tourism industry," Journal of Productivity Analysis, vol. 59, no. 2, pp. 243–258, June 2023. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1007/s11123-023-00665-4
Summary: This paper investigates the multidimensional productivity of the Italian tourism sector from 2011 to 2020, emphasizing both cross-sectoral and spatial spillover effects using georeferenced firm-level data aggregated by Local Labour Market Areas (LMAs). Employing a Cobb-Douglas-based spatial econometric model, the study reveals that tourism productivity in Italy is shaped by the interplay among inputs from Accommodation, Restaurants, Creative & Arts, Entertainment, and Transport sectors, as well as by spillover effectsboth positive and negativeacross neighboring destinations. Results demonstrate that these effects and the significance of specific input factors vary notably across tourism segments (city, sea, mountain), calling for segment-specific, cluster-based policy interventions to leverage agglomeration benefits and mitigate negative competitive pressures. The research highlights the necessity for collaborative networks between tourism organizations to maximize local and neighboring area competitiveness and suggests future work on distinguishing intra- and inter-sectoral spillovers, considering more flexible production function forms, and addressing potential productive inefficiencies.

Summary: This paper examines strategies for implementing the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) with Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) to enable small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to adapt during the digital disruption age, particularly since SMEs often lack extensive R&D resources. Reviewing 30 recent articles from leading publishers, the study analyzes IIoT drivers, strategies, capabilities, and benefits, and develops key adoption items based on the Technology, Organization, and Environment (TOE) framework, with data from 325 respondents in Thailand's manufacturing sector. The findings highlight four major adoption factors: lightweight flexibility, non-monotonous tasks enabled by new HCI, real-time top management decision-making, and the expansion of market opportunities. By identifying these elements, the study guides SMEs in effectively adopting IIoT with HCI to maximize business value.

Summary: Digital twin (DT) technology enables seamless integration of physical and digital systems throughout a product's life cycleincluding design, manufacturing, operation, and maintenanceby synchronizing virtual representations with their real-world counterparts in real time. Summary: As the global industrial landscape advances toward Industry 4.0, technologies such as distributed ledger technology (DLT), digital twins, and artificial intelligence are critical enablers; recently, the concept of the metaverse has also emerged as pivotal in enabling digitally advanced engineering domains by fusing distributed computing, digital-physical evolution, and advanced learning systems. Ensuring privacy, integrity, and confidentiality of personal data in these interconnected environments necessitates robust identity management, but traditional centralized solutions may be insufficient for the metaverse's complexity. Citation: E. Ö. Alakaş, "Digital transformational leadership and organizational agility in digital transformation: Structural equation modelling of the moderating effects of digital culture and digital strategy," The Journal of High Technology Management Research, vol. 35, no. 2, Article 100517, Nov. 2024. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.hitech.2024.100517
Summary: This study examines how digital transformational leadership affects organizational agility within the realm of digital transformation (DT), employing a quantitative research design with data collected from managers in organizations across various sectors actively engaging in DT. Using structural equation modeling (SEM), the findings demonstrate that digital transformational leadership significantly enhances organizational agility, while digital culture and digital strategy both serve as significant positive moderatorsmeaning they strengthen the leadership-agility relationship. Constructs were measured using validated scales with reliability confirmed by Cronbach's alpha and CFA. The presence of a strong digital culture (one encouraging innovation and digital mindsets) and a clear digital strategy both amplify the positive impact of leadership, as shown by significant interaction effects and satisfactory SEM model fit. The discussion underscores that while investment in digital leadership is vital, parallel efforts to foster supportive culture and articulate coherent strategy are essential for agile DT outcomes. Organizations face challenges aligning leadership with fast-paced technological shifts, nurturing digital culture in legacy environments, formulating adaptive strategies, and overcoming resistance to change, with future research recommended to explore longitudinal and contextual variations as well as additional moderating or mediating factors. Empirically, the study validates that digital transformational leadership is critical for agility in DT, and its impact is most pronounced when complemented by enabling culture and strategy.

Summary: This paper presents a simulation-based evaluation of the electric vehicle (EV) powertrain, focusing on the performance of various powertrain configurations under different settings using MATLAB Simulink. The system modeled consists of a permanent magnet synchronous motor, power converter with gate drivers, controller, and battery, designed for a four-wheeler passenger car. Theoretical calculations based on vehicle specifications were conducted to examine the EV's performance, demonstrating the effectiveness of simulation in reducing time and cost associated with complex system design. The simulation model is highlighted as a valuable tool for assessing control algorithms and enabling co-simulation with broader vehicle simulation programs, with results confirming the EV's suitability for operation in diverse road conditions.
